summary: This is a court order by Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding redaction and sealing requests in the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell. The order grants most of the government's and defendant's redaction requests to protect third-party privacy and ongoing investigations but denies some requests for being insufficiently justified or not narrowly tailored.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case (20-CR-330) who filed objections to the government's proposed redactions.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge issuing the order, analyzing redaction requests under the Lugosch test and balancing the presumption of access against privacy and law enforcement interests.

connections.description: Prosecution vs. defendant relationship in the criminal case 20-CR-330.
Defendant and presiding judge in the criminal case.

events.title: Government files omnibus opposition brief
events.description: The Government filed its omnibus memorandum of law opposing Defendant's twelve pre-trial motions under temporary seal.

events.title: Defendant objects to proposed redactions
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell objected to certain government-proposed redactions and proposed additional redactions.

events.title: Court issues redaction order
events.description: Judge Nathan issues an order granting most redaction requests but denying some, giving the government until March 22 to justify certain requests.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
keyFacts: The court applies the Lugosch test to balance the common law/First Amendment presumption of access to judicial documents against countervailing interests like privacy and law enforcement integrity.
Redactions are largely granted to protect third-party names, contact information, and private family affairs, with the court emphasizing these privacy interests 'should weigh heavily'.

The court denies the government's redaction requests for pages 1-128 and 187-188 of its brief, and for sealing Exhibits 8 and 9, finding the requests not narrowly tailored and lacking non-conclusory justification.
The government is given until March 22, 2021, to file a letter justifying more tailored redaction requests for the denied portions or to indicate it will not renew the request.
The order references sealed proceedings before different judges relating to the issuance of grand jury subpoenas in connection with the Maxwell case.
